block.p: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

''BERLIN TO BROADWAY WITH KURT WEILL,'' Triad, 158 West 72nd Street, (212) 279-4200 until Thursday; after that, (212) 239-6200. If this is not a flawless revue, it is nevertheless an ingratiating tribute to his achievement. Fridays, Mondays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Wednesdays at 3 and 8 p.m.; no show this Monday but an added performance Sunday at 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $45 (Lawrence Van Gelder).
A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

''BERLIN TO BROADWAY WITH KURT WEILL,'' Triad, 158 West 72nd Street, (212) 279-4200 until Thursday; after that, (212) 239-6200. If this is not a flawless revue, it is nevertheless an ingratiating tribute to his achievement. Fridays, Mondays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Wednesdays at 3 and 8 p.m.; no show this Monday but an added performance Sunday at 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $45 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

QUEEN ESTHER, Joe's Pub, Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. The artist exudes an impish charm that recalls the sorely missed comedian and performance artist Danitra Vance. But by the end of the show her musical identity remains undefined. Her nondescript versions of ''The Lady Is a Tramp'' and ''Lush Life'' fail to illuminate either the material or her ideas. And when she caps her show with two more vintage lounge songs, ''I've Gotta Be Me'' and ''The Good Life,'' it isn't clear whether she's making fun of them or embracing them. The best moments of ''Unemployed Superstar'' are the nonmusical monologues in which Queen Esther impersonates embittered neighbors she met when she moved to Harlem. Characters like these could form the basis of an unsettling evening of serious political comedy. Tonight at 8:30. Tickets: $12. Also at Joe's Pub, tomorrow at 8:30 p.m., Liza Jessie Peterson, singer, in the funk opera ''Chiron's Homegirl Healer Howls'' and new work. Tickets: $12. Sunday at 9 p.m., Eszter Balint, singer and songwriter. Tickets: $10 (Stephen Holden).

* ''OUR SINATRA,'' Reprise Room at Dillon's, 245 West 54th Street, (212) 239-6200. The rising young cabaret star Eric Comstock is the mastermind behind this utterly winning tribute to Ol' Blue Eyes. He focuses on what he calls the hidden gems and orphan songs that Sinatra made popular. Joined by Christopher Gines, whose creamy baritone echoes Dick Haymes and Steve Lawrence in their prime, and Hilary Kole, a perky swinger, Mr. Comstock conducts a witty and knowledgeable survey of the Sinatra canon. Mr. Comstock concentrates on the mature Sinatra and Mr. Gines on the dreamy 1940's balladeer, with Ms. Kole bridging the gap. The memorable show proves that there are still young singers good enough to keep the tradition alive. Tonight, Monday and Tuesday nights at 8, tomorrow and Wednesdays at 2:30 and 8 p.m., Sunday nights at 7:30. Tickets: $50 and $55; ringside seating, $75 and $80 (Holden).

BEMELMANS BAR, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 744-1600. Peter Mintun, pianist. Tuesday through Saturday nights beginning at 9:30. Through Oct. 14. Cover: $15 at table and $5 at the bar; no minimum.

CARNEGIE CLUB, 156 West 56th Street, (212) 957-9676. Cary Hoffman, with the 11-piece Carnegie Club Orchestra, plays music made famous by Frank Sinatra in the 1950's, featuring the original arrangements by Nelson Riddle. Friday and Saturday nights at 9:30 and 11. Cover, $20; two-drink ($15) minimum.

CAFE PIERRE, Fifth Avenue at 61st Street, (212) 940-8195. Friday and Saturday nights from 8:30 to 12:30; Tuesday through Thursday nights, 8:30 to 11:30, Kathleen Landis, singer and pianist, in ''Fascinating Rhythms: 50 Years of American Popular Song and Jazz, 1900-1950.'' Sunday and Monday nights from 8:30 to 11:30, Nancy Winston. No cover; $20 minimum.

DANNY'S SKYLIGHT ROOM, 346 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 265-8133. Tonight at 7, Marcy Heisler and Zina Goldrich, singers; from 9 p.m. to 1:00 p.m. in the piano bar, Jerry Scott, no cover; and in the cabaret room at 9:15 p.m., the singer Margy Seides. Cover: $12. Tomorrow night in the cabaret room at 7 p.m. Clark Warren, singer. Cover: $13. Tomorrow night from 9 to 1 in the piano bar, Jerry Scott. No cover. Sunday at 7:00 p.m. in the cabaret room, Toshi Kajiyama. Cover: $10 and $10 minimum.

DON'T TELL MAMA, 343 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 757-0788. Tonight at 7, ''The Stand-Up Comedy Experience''; at 8, ''The Next Big Broadway Musical,'' improvisational musical comedy; at 9, Sam Servello, singer, with Rick Jensen, pianist; at 11, Ron Seykell, Broadway singer. Tomorrow at 4:30 p.m., Claire Brosseau, singer; at 6, Parker Scott, singer, with Gerry Dieffenbach, pianist; at 6:30, Sylvia Reichman, singer; at 8:30, Tommy Femia impersonates Judy Garland; also at 8:30, ''Poole Party!,'' comedy with Ron Poole and guests; at 11, Steven Brinberg impersonates Barbra Streisand. Sunday at 3 p.m., Claire Brosseau, singer; at 3:30 p.m., Candace Palladino, singer, with Beth Goodrich, pianist; at 8, ''Camp Adrianne for Girls,'' comedy, with Adrianne Tolsch. Cover: Free to $18. Two-drink minimum. No credit cards.
DUPLEX, 61 Christopher Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 255-5438. Fridays at 8 p.m., ''Shout,'' pop revue. Through Sept. 22. Cover: $12; two-drink minimum. No credit cards.

FIREBIRD CAFE, 363 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 586-0244. Tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11, Jackie and Roy, singers. Cover: $30 plus $15 minimum. Sunday at 6:30 p.m., Ann Hampton Callaway. Cover: $30 plus a $15 minimum. Sunday, at 9 p.m., Barbara Fasano. Cover: $20 plus $15 minimum.
FEINSTEIN'S, at the Regency, 540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street, (212) 339-4095. Cleo Laine, singer, opens Tuesday; through Sept. 23.

JUDY'S, 169 Eighth Avenue, at 18th Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-5410. Tonight at 8:30, Anne Pringle and Mark Burnell, singers, in ''Duets and Duets.'' Tomorrow at 8:30 p.m., Annie Hughes, singer. Sunday at 3 p.m., Peter York, singer, Robert Kaye, pianist; at 5:30 p.m., Colette Thompson, singer, David Shaeffer, pianist; at 8:30 p.m., Mark Hartman, pianist, in ''The Song Is You,'' with guest singers. Cover: $10 to $20; $10 minimum.

SUPPER CLUB, 240 West 47th Street, (212) 921-1940. Tonight and tomorrow night from 8 to midnight, the Supper Club's 16-piece big band. Also, the 30-minute revue ''This Joint Is Jumpin','' with Larry Marshall, Fridays and Saturdays at 9:30 and 10:30 p.m. Swing dance lessons every Friday and Saturday night from 11:15 p.m. to midnight in the Blue Room. Tonight, the Jumpin' Gigolos; tomorrow night, the Jet Set Six, from 12:30 to 2:30 a.m. Cover: $25 before 11, $15 after.

OAK ROOM, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 840-6800. Maureen McGovern, singer, through Oct. 14. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11:30; Tuesdays through Thursdays at 9 p.m. Cover: $50, with dinner required for early shows on Fridays and Saturdays; $15 minimum for other shows; suggested dinner arrival for early show is 7. Sunday jazz brunch, at 2 p.m. (seating begins at 12:30 p.m.), Judy Barnett, singer. Cover: $50, includes brunch. International Festival of Cabaret: Sunday at 9 p.m., Natalie Gamsu, singer; Monday at 6 and 8 p.m., Michelle Hermon, singer; $40 cover and $15 minimum; Sundays and Mondays through October.
